facts.fact: Sports Betting Model System project initiated with focus on NBA and MLB player props

NBA Player Prop Modeling Research completed: identified statistical approaches (linear regression, gradient boosting, neural networks), key predictors (recent performance, opponent strength, rest days, home/away), and evaluation methods (RMSE, MAE, Sharpe ratio)

MLB Pitcher Prop Modeling Research completed: identified statistical approaches (Poisson regression, random forest, XGBoost), key predictors (FIP, ERA, strikeouts/9, opponent lineup strength), and importance of regression to mean

Data Sources Research completed: documented free APIs (nba_api, MLB-StatsAPI, baseball-scraper), cheap providers (Action Network API, BetRivers API, OddsMatrix), and access methods for real-time and historical data

Open Source Betting Models Research completed: cataloged 15+ GitHub repos, identified common techniques (Kelly criterion, Elo ratings, Poisson models), and best practices (unit management, bankroll tracking, disciplined staking)

Tech stack established: Python 3.10+, SQLAlchemy for database, nba_api for NBA data, MLB-StatsAPI for MLB data, scikit-learn for classical ML, xgboost for gradient boosting, pandas/numpy for data manipulation
Core infrastructure created: database.py (SQLAlchemy models for games, players, props, bets), data_fetcher.py (API integration for NBA/MLB data), main.py (application entry point)
Research documentation created: 4 comprehensive markdown files covering NBA player props, MLB pitcher props, data sources, and open source models
Next development priorities: feature engineering (rolling averages, player matchups, situational factors), baseline model implementation, backtesting framework, live odds integration

Key modeling insight: Player performance is highly variable; recent form (last 5-10 games) is more predictive than season averages; situational context (back-to-back, travel, rest days) significantly impacts performance
